content:
I think the math and/or physics of this dont really check out, especially since its not clearly specified, how the change of speed occurs.

Without having looked at this with any depth, I think the math only checks out if the speed change happens non-continously at full seconds, which is not how trains work, traditionally.

If this is how its supposed to be, then at least it should  be mentioned that physics is being violated, as, if one is being told that "the train's speed decreases by half  every second", one would not expect this to happen in large quanta.

I think you should change input types to ints, because floats might cause unexpected errors due to precision
Also is "Impssoble" a typo?

I think the idea might be good, but the statement is not very clear. Currently, I think that all the exercice is based on the knowledge of the problem itself. In my opinion, it needs more detailled explanations, or more tips to find the solution; if not it's too hard for a clash of code. For now, I find that it's not very interesting, sorry.

The 2nd example with S=40 and L=100, shouldn't that be false? 

Also, I think you should state that the 1st example (L=10, S=5) would be false. The way it is stated now, it is ambiguous whether that situation is considered true or false. I suggest rewording the sentence: 
"The speed will just get smaller and smaller to be like 0.000000596 feet/second, so unless there is a trick..." 
to something like:
"The speed will continue to get smaller and smaller but will never reach 0 feet/second. Therefor the output would be false (because the train would only ever be able to reach 9.9999999999... feet and not 10 feet)." The stuff in parentheses aren't necessarily needed, but it will help explain why this example is false.

I think it is very fun but it was hard for me to find the trick only by the example you gave... I looked through the testcases and then I got it so I think you should add 1 or 2 other examples and at least one of the emple should be false
It was fun to solve, hope to see this in clash of code ^-^
Why is the case 2S = L considered "false"? Because you don't reach the end in a *finite* amount of time? I think the statement should be clearer about that.
Simple, might be good for speed codes
To make it more interesting, you can output exactly at which second does the train reach its destination, if it doesn't reach the destination at all, output "Won't reach".

true/false is more commonly used than True/False

Please make them all lowercase :)

This argument is kinda pointless.
First: there are already many puzzles that use True/False in this way
Second: it would be actually better not to use native values from any languages

So in my opition printin something like: 'Can make it/Can't make it'
is much better then true/false, True/False or anything else

I changed the statement to be a bit clearer.
Thanks for the feedback!

I had them be floats because in some languages like C++, dividing an int (like 5) by 2 would equal 2 not 2.5. Anyways, I changed the inputs to have decimal places. 
Sorry about the typo. 

Thanks for the feedback!

It is not pointless ... because you are setting this as golf code ...

Some languages are cheated and print "True" when the code is print(0<1)

For fair-play, i aggre with  BenjaminUrquhart's comment

Yeah you are right, pointless may not be the correct wording here. :)

But as you also stated, some languages use uppercase true/false, so it should not be used neiither of them, but something completly different.
I changed it to lowercase "true/false." Thanks for the feedback!
